TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit Cursors extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides a collection of objects for use by a Windows Forms application.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Some of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursor> objects in this class can take on a different appearance than those described. The user can change the cursor appearance by adjusting the mouse pointer settings in their operating system. The panning and no move cursors are static and cannot be changed by the operating system.
The panning and no move cursors are used during mouse wheel operations. Depending on the direction the window can be scrolled, the cursor changes to the appropriate no move cursor when the mouse wheel is clicked. The cursor then changes to the appropriate panning cursor as the mouse is moved.
## Examples The following example demonstrates changing the mouse cursor using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Cursor%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursor> class, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursors> class. The example creates a form that contains a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> control, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel> control, and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> control. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox> contains all cursors provided by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursors> class. When the user selects a mouse cursor in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComboBox>, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Cursor%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property is set to the selected cursor, which updates the cursor for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Panel>. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ListView> is updated every time the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.CursorChanged?displayProperty=fullName> event occurs.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.Cursors#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Cursors/CPP/cursorexample.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.Cursors#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Cursors/CS/cursorexample.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.Cursors#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Cursors/VB/cursorexample.vb#1)]
The following example draws the specified cursor on the form in its normal size, and in stretched mode, twice its size. This example assumes that you have a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursor> object to pass into the method when it is called.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.Cursor Members#2](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Cursor Members/CPP/cursorstuff.cpp#2)] [!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.Cursor Members#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Cursor Members/CS/cursorstuff.cs#2)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.Cursor Members#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.Cursor Members/VB/cursorstuff.vb#2)]

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears when an application starts.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears when an application starts.

Docs.summary: Gets the arrow cursor.
Docs.value: The that represents the arrow cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the crosshair cursor.
Docs.value: The that represents the crosshair cursor.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following example demonstrates the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursors> class. To run this example place paste the following code in a form and call the InitializeRadioButtonsAndGroupBox method from the form's constructor or Load method. Ensure all events are connected to their event-handling methods.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.GroupBoxRadioButtonExample#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.GroupBoxRadioButtonExample/CPP/form1.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.GroupBoxRadioButtonExample#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.GroupBoxRadioButtonExample/CS/form1.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.GroupBoxRadioButtonExample#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.GroupBoxRadioButtonExample/VB/form1.vb#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets the default cursor, which is usually an arrow cursor.
Docs.value: The that represents the default cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the hand cursor, typically used when hovering over a Web link.
Docs.value: The that represents the hand cursor.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.OnMouseHover%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method in a derived class and using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Cursors.Hand%2A> property. To run the example, paste the following code in a new form and paste this class, forming the same file, after the form. Add a button of type FunButton to the form.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.ControlDefaultProperties#2](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.ControlDefaultProperties/CPP/form1.cpp#2)] [!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.ControlDefaultProperties#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.ControlDefaultProperties/CS/form1.cs#2)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.ControlDefaultProperties#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.ControlDefaultProperties/VB/form1.vb#2)]

Docs.summary: Gets the Help cursor, which is a combination of an arrow and a question mark.
Docs.value: The that represents the Help cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a horizontal splitter bar.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a horizontal splitter bar.

Docs.summary: Gets the I-beam cursor, which is used to show where the text cursor appears when the mouse is clicked.
Docs.value: The that represents the I-beam cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that indicates that a particular region is invalid for the current operation.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that indicates that a particular region is invalid for the current operation.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving, but the window can be scrolled in both a horizontal and vertical direction.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving, but the window can be scrolled in a horizontal direction.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving, but the window can be scrolled in a vertical direction.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is not moving.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the right.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the right.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the right.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the right.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in an upward direction.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in an upward direction.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the left.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically upward and to the left.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the right.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the right.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in a downward direction.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling vertically in a downward direction.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the left.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally and vertically downward and to the left.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the left.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears during wheel operations when the mouse is moving and the window is scrolling horizontally to the left.

Docs.summary: Gets the four-headed sizing cursor, which consists of four joined arrows that point north, south, east, and west.
Docs.value: The that represents the four-headed sizing cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the two-headed diagonal (northeast/southwest) sizing cursor.
Docs.value: The that represents two-headed diagonal (northeast/southwest) sizing cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the two-headed vertical (north/south) sizing cursor.
Docs.value: The that represents the two-headed vertical (north/south) sizing cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the two-headed diagonal (northwest/southeast) sizing cursor.
Docs.value: The that represents the two-headed diagonal (northwest/southeast) sizing cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the two-headed horizontal (west/east) sizing cursor.
Docs.value: The that represents the two-headed horizontal (west/east) sizing cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the up arrow cursor, typically used to identify an insertion point.
Docs.value: The that represents the up arrow cursor.

Docs.summary: Gets the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a vertical splitter bar.
Docs.value: The that represents the cursor that appears when the mouse is positioned over a vertical splitter bar.

Docs.summary: Gets the wait cursor, typically an hourglass shape.
Docs.value: The that represents the wait cursor.

remarks.format: ## Remarks To force display of the wait cursor over a given control, call that control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.UseWaitCursor%2A> method. To make the wait cursor display for the entire application, regardless of the control or form selected, call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application.UseWaitCursor%2A> on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application> class.
